title: Ruth Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ruth chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ruth Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ruth Chapter 3.

questions.question: Who suggested seeking rest for Ruth in Ruth 3?
options: Naomi
Boaz
Ruth
Elimelech
questions.correctAnswer: Naomi
questions.explanation: Naomi, Ruth's mother-in-law, said to her, 'My daughter, shall I not seek rest for thee' (Ruth 3:1).

questions.question: Where was Boaz winnowing barley according to Ruth 3?
options: In the threshingfloor
In the marketplace
By the river
In the house
questions.correctAnswer: In the threshingfloor
questions.explanation: Boaz was winnowing barley in the threshingfloor at night (Ruth 3:2).

questions.question: What did Naomi tell Ruth to do before going to Boaz at the threshingfloor?
options: Wash herself, anoint herself, and put on her raiment
Prepare food for Boaz
Sing a song
Bring gifts
questions.correctAnswer: Wash herself, anoint herself, and put on her raiment
questions.explanation: Naomi instructed Ruth to wash, anoint, and put on her raiment before going (Ruth 3:3).

questions.question: What was Ruth instructed to do when Boaz lay down to sleep?
options: Uncover his feet and lay down
Wake him up
Leave immediately
Speak loudly to him
questions.correctAnswer: Uncover his feet and lay down
questions.explanation: Ruth was told to uncover Boaz's feet and lay down after he lay down (Ruth 3:4).

questions.question: True or False: Ruth refused to obey Naomi's instructions in Ruth 3.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ruth said she would do all that Naomi said (Ruth 3:5).

questions.question: What was Boaz doing when Ruth came to him at the threshingfloor?
options: He had eaten, drunk, and was merry
He was sleeping
He was working
He was praying
questions.correctAnswer: He had eaten, drunk, and was merry
questions.explanation: Boaz had eaten and drunk, and his heart was merry when Ruth came (Ruth 3:7).

questions.question: At what time of night did Boaz notice Ruth lying at his feet?
options: Midnight
Evening
Dawn
Noon
questions.correctAnswer: Midnight
questions.explanation: It was at midnight that Boaz was afraid and turned himself (Ruth 3:8).

questions.question: What did Ruth call herself when Boaz asked who she was?
options: Thine handmaid
A stranger
A servant of the LORD
A friend
questions.correctAnswer: Thine handmaid
questions.explanation: Ruth answered, 'I am Ruth thine handmaid' (Ruth 3:9).

questions.question: What did Boaz say Ruth had shown more kindness in the latter end than at the beginning?
options: Not following young men
Helping Naomi
Working in the fields
Praying
questions.correctAnswer: Not following young men
questions.explanation: Boaz blessed Ruth for showing more kindness by not following young men, whether poor or rich (Ruth 3:10).

questions.question: True or False: Boaz was the nearest kinsman to Ruth who could redeem her.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Boaz said there was a kinsman nearer than he (Ruth 3:12).

questions.question: What did Boaz say he would do if the nearer kinsman refused to redeem Ruth?
options: He would do the part of a kinsman
He would leave and do nothing
He would marry someone else
He would sell the land
questions.correctAnswer: He would do the part of a kinsman
questions.explanation: Boaz promised to do the part of a kinsman if the nearer kinsman refused (Ruth 3:13).

questions.question: How long did Ruth stay at Boaz's feet that night?
options: Until the morning
A few hours
Until midnight
Only until he woke up
questions.correctAnswer: Until the morning
questions.explanation: Ruth lay at his feet until the morning (Ruth 3:14).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Boaz gave Ruth six measures of ______ before she went into the city.
options: barley
wheat
corn
oil
questions.correctAnswer: barley
questions.explanation: Boaz gave Ruth six measures of barley (Ruth 3:15).

questions.question: Who asked Ruth 'Who art thou, my daughter?' when she returned to the city?
options: Naomi
Boaz
The nearer kinsman
A city elder
questions.correctAnswer: Naomi
questions.explanation: Naomi asked Ruth who she was when she returned (Ruth 3:16).

questions.question: True or False: Naomi said Boaz would rest until he finished the matter that day.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Naomi said Boaz would not be at rest until he finished the thing that day (Ruth 3:18).

medium.title: Ruth Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ruth Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Ruth 3:1 teach us about trusting God’s provision in difficult circumstances?
options: Naomi seeks rest and well-being for Ruth through family support
Ruth must work harder to earn her own rest
God will provide without any human help
Rest comes only after wealth is gained
questions.correctAnswer: Naomi seeks rest and well-being for Ruth through family support
questions.explanation: Ruth 3:1 shows Naomi’s concern to find rest for Ruth, indicating trust in God’s provision through family kindness (Ruth 3:1, 3:11, 3:18).

questions.question: What does Naomi instruct Ruth to do before going to the threshing floor according to Ruth 3:3?
options: Wash, anoint herself, put on her best clothes, and go down to the threshing floor
Prepare food and wait outside
Speak openly to Boaz before he finishes eating
Ask Boaz for money first
questions.correctAnswer: Wash, anoint herself, put on her best clothes, and go down to the threshing floor
questions.explanation: Ruth 3:3 commands Ruth to prepare herself physically and respectfully before meeting Boaz, illustrating obedience and reverence (Ruth 3:3, 3:6, 3:7).

questions.question: How does Ruth demonstrate obedience and humility in Ruth 3:5?
options: She agrees to do all that Naomi instructs her
She questions Naomi’s plan
She asks Boaz directly for help
She refuses to go to the threshing floor
questions.correctAnswer: She agrees to do all that Naomi instructs her
questions.explanation: Ruth 3:5 shows her humble and obedient heart, crucial for trusting God’s plan through wise counsel (Ruth 3:5, 3:6, 3:11).

questions.question: What does Boaz’s reaction at midnight teach us about integrity and kindness in Ruth 3:10?
options: He blesses Ruth for her loyalty and kindness, showing his integrity
He rejects Ruth immediately
He is angry about being disturbed
He demands payment for helping Ruth
questions.correctAnswer: He blesses Ruth for her loyalty and kindness, showing his integrity
questions.explanation: Boaz’s blessing in Ruth 3:10 highlights his integrity and appreciation for Ruth’s faithfulness, modeling kindness and respect (Ruth 3:9, 3:10, 3:11).

questions.question: Based on Ruth 3:12-13, what biblical principle about responsibility and patience is taught?
options: Boaz recognizes another closer kinsman and waits for the right time
Boaz immediately claims Ruth without consideration
Ruth must find a new husband elsewhere
Naomi arranges a marriage with a stranger
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz recognizes another closer kinsman and waits for the right time
questions.explanation: Boaz’s respect for legal order and patience teaches faithfulness to God’s timing and responsibility (Ruth 3:12-13, 3:18).

questions.question: What spiritual lesson can be drawn from Ruth lying at Boaz’s feet all night according to Ruth 3:14?
options: She demonstrates trust and faith in God’s protection through humility
She forces Boaz to marry her
She tries to hide from everyone
She shows fear and runs away
questions.correctAnswer: She demonstrates trust and faith in God’s protection through humility
questions.explanation: Ruth 3:14 reveals her faith and humility as she trusts Boaz and God’s plan, showing perseverance in trials (Ruth 3:14, 3:5, 3:11).

questions.question: How does Boaz’s instruction to keep Ruth’s visit secret (Ruth 3:14) relate to wisdom in dealing with delicate situations?
options: It shows discretion and respect for reputations
It encourages gossip
It causes Ruth shame
It means hiding sin
questions.correctAnswer: It shows discretion and respect for reputations
questions.explanation: Boaz’s carefulness in Ruth 3:14 teaches wisdom in protecting others’ dignity and maintaining integrity (Ruth 3:14, 3:11).

questions.question: What does Boaz giving Ruth six measures of barley symbolize in Ruth 3:15 regarding generosity and provision?
options: God’s generous provision through Boaz’s kindness
Boaz’s attempt to buy Ruth’s silence
Ruth’s payment for marriage
A gift without meaning
questions.correctAnswer: God’s generous provision through Boaz’s kindness
questions.explanation: Boaz’s gift in Ruth 3:15 represents God’s blessing and generosity, encouraging believers to practice stewardship and kindness (Ruth 3:15, 3:17).

questions.question: How does Ruth’s report to Naomi in Ruth 3:16-17 demonstrate faith and encouragement?
options: She shares God’s favor and provision, encouraging patience
She complains about Boaz
She hides the truth from Naomi
She decides to leave the city
questions.correctAnswer: She shares God’s favor and provision, encouraging patience
questions.explanation: Ruth 3:16-17 shows her trust in God’s plan and encourages hope and patience in trials (Ruth 3:16-18, 3:1).

questions.question: How does Naomi’s advice to Ruth in Ruth 3:18 teach perseverance and trusting God’s timing?
options: She tells Ruth to wait quietly until the matter is resolved
She urges Ruth to seek another husband
She encourages Ruth to confront the kinsman
She advises Ruth to leave town
questions.correctAnswer: She tells Ruth to wait quietly until the matter is resolved
questions.explanation: Naomi’s counsel in Ruth 3:18 highlights patience and trusting God’s providence in difficult circumstances (Ruth 3:18, 3:13, 3:1).

questions.question: True or False: Ruth immediately revealed her identity to Boaz before he finished eating and drinking (Ruth 3:3-7).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ruth 3:3 instructs her not to make herself known until Boaz has finished eating and drinking, showing respect and patience (Ruth 3:3, 3:7).

questions.question: True or False: Boaz admits there is a closer kinsman than himself who has the right to redeem Ruth (Ruth 3:12).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Boaz acknowledges another closer relative in Ruth 3:12, demonstrating honesty and respect for legal rights (Ruth 3:12-13).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Naomi tells Ruth she will seek ______ for her that she may have rest (Ruth 3:1).
options: rest
wealth
fame
strength
questions.correctAnswer: rest
questions.explanation: Naomi’s goal is to find rest for Ruth, indicating care and desire for her well-being (Ruth 3:1, 3:18).

questions.question: How does Ruth’s action of uncovering Boaz’s feet (Ruth 3:4, 3:7) illustrate humility and submission in a biblical context?
options: It is a respectful gesture acknowledging Boaz’s role as kinsman redeemer
It is an act of disrespect
It shows Ruth forcing Boaz to marry her
It is unrelated to humility
questions.correctAnswer: It is a respectful gesture acknowledging Boaz’s role as kinsman redeemer
questions.explanation: Ruth 3:4 and 3:7 describe her humble submission, trusting God’s plan through Boaz’s kindness (Ruth 3:4, 3:9, 3:11).

questions.question: How does Ruth 3:11 emphasize the importance of a good reputation in the community?
options: Boaz states the city knows Ruth is a virtuous woman
Boaz ignores the community’s opinion
Ruth is known for gossiping
The city doubts Ruth’s character
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz states the city knows Ruth is a virtuous woman
questions.explanation: In Ruth 3:11, Boaz affirms Ruth’s good reputation as evidence of her character, encouraging integrity and witness in community (Ruth 3:11, 3:10).

hard.title: Ruth Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ruth Chapter 3.

questions.question: What cultural practice does Naomi suggest Ruth use to seek rest and security for herself?
options: Approaching the threshing floor to seek Boaz's protection
Delivering a public speech in the city gates
Offering a sacrifice at the temple
Seeking a new husband among the Moabites
questions.correctAnswer: Approaching the threshing floor to seek Boaz's protection
questions.explanation: Naomi instructs Ruth to go to the threshing floor where Boaz is winnowing barley, a known custom for a kinsman-redeemer proposal (Ruth 3:2-4).

questions.question: What is the significance of Ruth uncovering Boaz's feet and lying down there?
options: It symbolized a humble appeal for protection and a marriage proposal
It was a sign of disrespect in their culture
It meant she was claiming ownership of his property
It was a secret ritual to curse an enemy
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolized a humble appeal for protection and a marriage proposal
questions.explanation: Uncovering the feet and lying down at them was a culturally symbolic act implying a request for Boaz to assume his role as kinsman-redeemer (Ruth 3:4, 7-9).

questions.question: How does Boaz describe Ruth's kindness compared to the beginning of her story?
options: She has shown more kindness in the latter end than at the beginning
She has been less kind than before
Her kindness has remained the same
She has only shown kindness to Naomi
questions.correctAnswer: She has shown more kindness in the latter end than at the beginning
questions.explanation: Boaz blesses Ruth for showing greater loyalty and kindness toward Naomi now than when she first came (Ruth 3:10).

questions.question: Who does Boaz say is a nearer kinsman than himself?
options: Another relative with a stronger claim to redeem
Boaz himself is the closest
No other kinsman exists
A Moabite man from Ruth's homeland
questions.correctAnswer: Another relative with a stronger claim to redeem
questions.explanation: Boaz reveals there is a closer kinsman who has the right to redeem before he can act (Ruth 3:12).

questions.question: What does Boaz give Ruth when she leaves the threshing floor?
options: Six measures of barley
A golden ring
A written contract
A loaf of bread
questions.correctAnswer: Six measures of barley
questions.explanation: Boaz gives Ruth six measures of barley as a gift and sign of his goodwill (Ruth 3:15-17).

questions.question: What Hebrew term relates to Boaz’s role as a near kinsman who redeems?
options: Goel (kinsman-redeemer)
Navi (prophet)
Kohen (priest)
Sopher (scribe)
questions.correctAnswer: Goel (kinsman-redeemer)
questions.explanation: Boaz acts as a 'goel,' the next of kin with the duty to redeem family property and marry the widow to preserve the lineage (Ruth 3:9-13).

questions.question: Which Old Testament law or custom is reflected in Boaz’s willingness to redeem Ruth?
options: Levirate marriage and redemption laws from Deuteronomy
Sacrificial laws from Leviticus
Covenant renewal ceremony from Exodus
Feast of Tabernacles regulations
questions.correctAnswer: Levirate marriage and redemption laws from Deuteronomy
questions.explanation: Boaz’s actions echo the Levirate marriage and property redemption laws to preserve family inheritance (cf. Deuteronomy 25:5-10).

questions.question: True or False: Ruth immediately identifies herself to Boaz when she approaches him at the threshing floor.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ruth directly tells Boaz she is his handmaid and asks him to spread his skirt over her, identifying herself clearly (Ruth 3:9).

questions.question: What does Boaz mean when he tells Ruth to "spread thy skirt over thine handmaid"?
options: To extend his protection and acknowledge her as his wife-to-be
To hide her identity from others
To share his cloak because of the cold
To cover her face in shame
questions.correctAnswer: To extend his protection and acknowledge her as his wife-to-be
questions.explanation: The phrase symbolizes Boaz’s acceptance of his role as kinsman-redeemer and protection over Ruth (Ruth 3:9).

questions.question: How does the narrative structure of Ruth 3 utilize time markers such as 'at night' and 'in the morning'?
options: To highlight the suspense and pivotal transition in the story
To indicate the passage of several days
To emphasize the agricultural calendar
To show a dream sequence
questions.correctAnswer: To highlight the suspense and pivotal transition in the story
questions.explanation: The use of 'at night' and 'in the morning' creates a literary structure emphasizing suspense and the turning point in Ruth's plight (Ruth 3:2, 8, 13-14).

questions.question: What does the giving of barley to Ruth foreshadow in the broader biblical narrative?
options: Provision and blessing through kinsman-redeemer, prefiguring Christ's redemption
The building of Solomon’s temple
The exile to Babylon
The destruction of Jericho
questions.correctAnswer: Provision and blessing through kinsman-redeemer, prefiguring Christ's redemption
questions.explanation: The barley symbolizes God’s provision and redemption through Boaz, a type of Christ’s ultimate redemption (Ruth 3:15).

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the dialogue between Boaz and Ruth when he acknowledges her virtue and promises to act?
options: Chiasm, emphasizing reversal and restoration
Simile comparing Ruth to a lion
Hyperbole describing Boaz’s wealth
Allegory of the vineyard
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm, emphasizing reversal and restoration
questions.explanation: The dialogue forms a chiastic structure highlighting Ruth’s transformation from vulnerable widow to favored bride (Ruth 3:10-13).

questions.question: Which theme evident in Ruth 3 is developed throughout Scripture, especially in the New Testament?
options: Redemption and God’s providential care
Judgment and punishment
Sacrificial offerings
Prophetic visions
questions.correctAnswer: Redemption and God’s providential care
questions.explanation: Ruth 3’s theme of redemption via a kinsman-redeemer anticipates the New Testament theme of Christ as Redeemer (Ruth 3:11-13).

questions.question: What was Naomi’s response after Ruth told her about the meeting with Boaz?
options: She urged Ruth to be patient until the matter unfolds
She told Ruth to confront the nearer kinsman immediately
She sent Ruth back to Moab
She went to the threshing floor herself
questions.correctAnswer: She urged Ruth to be patient until the matter unfolds
questions.explanation: Naomi instructs Ruth to wait quietly to see how the situation will develop, expressing confidence in Boaz (Ruth 3:16-18).

questions.question: What does the command "Let it not be known that a woman came into the floor" suggest about the cultural context?
options: That a woman’s presence at the threshing floor at night was socially sensitive or potentially scandalous
That women were not allowed to eat with men
That threshing floors were sacred and off-limits to everyone
That there was a law forbidding any visitors at the threshing floor
questions.correctAnswer: That a woman’s presence at the threshing floor at night was socially sensitive or potentially scandalous
questions.explanation: Boaz’s request reflects the cultural propriety and concern for reputation in ancient Israel (Ruth 3:14).

theological.title: Ruth Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ruth Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What theological significance can be drawn from Naomi's desire to 'seek rest' for Ruth in Ruth 3:1?
options: It reflects God's providential care and desire for covenantal blessing upon His people
It indicates human effort alone can secure salvation
It shows that rest is only a physical state, unrelated to spiritual well-being
It suggests Naomi doubted God's plan for Ruth
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects God's providential care and desire for covenantal blessing upon His people
questions.explanation: Naomi's wish to 'seek rest' for Ruth (Ruth 3:1) points to God's providential care, echoing biblical themes of rest as blessing (Exodus 33:14, Hebrews 4:9-10) and covenantal security (Genesis 15:1). This rest transcends physical comfort, symbolizing spiritual peace and salvation.

questions.question: In Ruth 3:2, Boaz is described as a 'kinsman.' What doctrinal truth about God's covenant people is revealed through this kinship?
options: God's covenant community is bound by familial loyalty and redemption responsibilities
Kinship is merely a social custom with no spiritual significance
Redemption is based on personal merit rather than covenant relationships
Only strangers can act as redeemers
questions.correctAnswer: God's covenant community is bound by familial loyalty and redemption responsibilities
questions.explanation: Boaz as a kinsman (Ruth 3:2) illustrates the biblical principle of the kinsman-redeemer (Leviticus 25:25, Deuteronomy 25:5-10, Isaiah 59:20), demonstrating God's design for community responsibility and redemption within His covenant people, prefiguring Christ's redemptive work.

questions.question: What does Naomi instruct Ruth to do before approaching Boaz in Ruth 3:3, and what spiritual symbolism can be derived from this?
options: Wash, anoint, and dress in her best clothes, symbolizing purification and preparation for divine encounter
Hide and avoid any interaction, symbolizing human fearfulness
Confront Boaz openly, symbolizing boldness without preparation
Pray silently without any outward change
questions.correctAnswer: Wash, anoint, and dress in her best clothes, symbolizing purification and preparation for divine encounter
questions.explanation: Naomi's instructions (Ruth 3:3) to wash, anoint, and dress are emblematic of spiritual purification (Psalm 51:7), anointing as God's blessing (1 Samuel 16:13), and readiness for covenant renewal (Ezekiel 36:25-27), indicating the necessity of holiness in approaching God's purposes.

questions.question: How does Ruth's obedience to Naomi's plan in Ruth 3:5 demonstrate a theological virtue essential for covenant life?
options: Faith and submission to God’s providential guidance
Self-reliance and independence from others
Skepticism and questioning of authority
Despair and passivity
questions.correctAnswer: Faith and submission to God’s providential guidance
questions.explanation: Ruth's response, 'All that thou sayest unto me I will do' (Ruth 3:5), exemplifies faith and submission, key virtues in covenant relationship (Hebrews 11:8, Proverbs 3:5-6), trusting God's providence through human agents without seeing the full outcome.

questions.question: What does Boaz's reaction to Ruth uncovering his feet in Ruth 3:8-9 symbolize in a Christological context?
options: The kinsman-redeemer's role of protection and covering
Shame and dishonor
Judgment and condemnation
Legalism without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: The kinsman-redeemer's role of protection and covering
questions.explanation: Boaz’s response (Ruth 3:8-9) to Ruth's act symbolizes the protective covering of the kinsman-redeemer, prefiguring Christ who covers and redeems His people (Isaiah 59:20, Galatians 3:13, Ephesians 1:7), offering both acceptance and salvation.

questions.question: In Ruth 3:10, Boaz blesses Ruth for showing more kindness in the latter end than at the beginning. What doctrine does this affirm about God's grace and human response?
options: God's grace is evident in perseverance and faithful covenant loyalty
Initial enthusiasm is sufficient for salvation
Kindness is irrelevant to spiritual life
Human works alone achieve salvation
questions.correctAnswer: God's grace is evident in perseverance and faithful covenant loyalty
questions.explanation: Boaz’s blessing (Ruth 3:10) highlights that grace is manifest in steadfast faithfulness, aligning with Scripture that values perseverance (James 1:12, Hebrews 10:36) and covenant loyalty as evidence of genuine relationship with God.

questions.question: What assurance does Boaz give Ruth in Ruth 3:11 about her standing before the community and God?
options: That she is recognized as a virtuous woman and will be treated with honor
That she will be rejected due to her background
That her future depends solely on luck
That she must prove herself through more works
questions.correctAnswer: That she is recognized as a virtuous woman and will be treated with honor
questions.explanation: Boaz’s assurance (Ruth 3:11) affirms Ruth’s virtuous character, reflecting biblical values of righteousness and honor (Proverbs 31:10, 1 Timothy 2:9-10), demonstrating that God’s people uphold and recognize godly character within the community.

questions.question: How does Boaz’s acknowledgment of another nearer kinsman in Ruth 3:12-13 teach about God’s justice and mercy in redemption?
options: God’s redemption plan respects legal rights but also ensures mercy through willing redeemers
Redemption is arbitrary and ignores justice
Mercy excludes justice in God’s dealings
Only the closest kinsman can redeem, regardless of willingness
questions.correctAnswer: God’s redemption plan respects legal rights but also ensures mercy through willing redeemers
questions.explanation: Boaz’s mention of a nearer kinsman (Ruth 3:12-13) shows respect for justice and legal rights, while his willingness to redeem if the other declines exemplifies God’s merciful provision (Isaiah 1:17, Micah 6:8, Romans 3:25). This balance reflects God’s perfect righteousness and grace.

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by Ruth lying at Boaz’s feet until morning as described in Ruth 3:14?
options: Trust in God’s timing and protection under His covenant
Human control over salvation
Fear and avoidance of God’s plan
Immediate fulfillment without waiting
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God’s timing and protection under His covenant
questions.explanation: Ruth’s patient waiting (Ruth 3:14) illustrates trust in God’s sovereign timing (Ecclesiastes 3:1, Psalm 27:14) and reliance on His protection within the covenant, a key biblical principle seen throughout Scripture (Habakkuk 2:3, Romans 8:28).

questions.question: Why does Boaz instruct that Ruth’s presence on the threshing floor be kept secret, according to Ruth 3:14?
options: To protect Ruth’s reputation and maintain community honor
To conceal sin and wrongdoing
To avoid legal consequences for Boaz
To hide Ruth’s identity as a foreigner
questions.correctAnswer: To protect Ruth’s reputation and maintain community honor
questions.explanation: Boaz’s desire for secrecy (Ruth 3:14) is to honor Ruth and safeguard her reputation, reflecting biblical concern for holiness, purity, and community witness (Proverbs 22:1, 1 Timothy 3:7), rather than concealment of sin.

questions.question: What is the significance of Boaz giving Ruth six measures of barley in Ruth 3:15 in light of God’s provision motif?
options: It symbolizes God’s abundant provision and covenantal blessing
It is a trivial gift with no deeper meaning
It indicates Boaz’s attempt to buy Ruth’s silence
It shows scarcity and lack of resources
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God’s abundant provision and covenantal blessing
questions.explanation: The gift of six measures of barley (Ruth 3:15) reflects God’s generous provision (Genesis 41:53-57, Philippians 4:19) and blessing upon those who trust Him, reinforcing the theme of divine care and covenantal faithfulness throughout Scripture.

questions.question: How does Ruth’s report to Naomi in Ruth 3:16-17 demonstrate faith and hope in God’s redemptive plan?
options: By openly sharing God’s provision and trusting in His ongoing work
By hiding the events out of fear
By expressing doubt about Boaz’s intentions
By making plans independent of God’s will
questions.correctAnswer: By openly sharing God’s provision and trusting in His ongoing work
questions.explanation: Ruth’s transparent report (Ruth 3:16-17) shows faith and hope, echoing biblical encouragement to trust and testify of God’s work (Psalm 27:13, Romans 8:24-25), supporting the believer’s confidence in God’s redemptive promises.

questions.question: What does Naomi’s instruction to 'Sit still, my daughter' in Ruth 3:18 reveal about the nature of trusting God in uncertain times?
options: It teaches patience and reliance on God’s sovereign timing
It encourages anxiety and impatience
It suggests taking immediate action without prayer
It promotes self-reliance over divine trust
questions.correctAnswer: It teaches patience and reliance on God’s sovereign timing
questions.explanation: Naomi’s counsel (Ruth 3:18) underscores patience and trust in God’s providence (Psalm 37:7, Isaiah 40:31), affirming that believers should wait on the Lord’s timing rather than act impulsively, a consistent biblical principle.

questions.question: How does the role of Boaz as a kinsman-redeemer in Ruth 3 illustrate the doctrine of Christ as our Redeemer?
options: Boaz’s willingness to redeem parallels Christ’s redemptive sacrifice for sinners
Boaz’s role is unrelated to Christ’s work
Boaz acts only out of human obligation, not grace
The kinsman-redeemer concept teaches self-salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz’s willingness to redeem parallels Christ’s redemptive sacrifice for sinners
questions.explanation: Boaz’s role (Ruth 3:9-13) prefigures Christ’s redeeming work (Galatians 4:4-5, Hebrews 9:15), demonstrating God’s grace in providing a redeemer who willingly restores and saves, fulfilling covenant promises beyond legal obligation (Isaiah 53:4-6).

questions.question: What aspect of God’s character is reflected in Ruth’s inclusion and Boaz’s acceptance of her, as seen in Ruth 3?
options: God’s inclusive grace extending to Gentiles and outsiders
God’s favor is limited to Israelite natives only
God’s judgment excludes foreigners
God’s law forbids association with outsiders
questions.correctAnswer: God’s inclusive grace extending to Gentiles and outsiders
questions.explanation: Ruth, a Moabite, is embraced (Ruth 3:10-11), illustrating God’s inclusive grace (Jonah 4:11, Acts 10:34-35), showing that salvation and covenant blessings extend to Gentiles who trust in God, consistent with the biblical narrative of God's redemptive plan.

questions.question: How does Ruth 3 teach about the interplay of human initiative and divine sovereignty in salvation history?
options: Human obedience works in harmony with God’s sovereign plan to accomplish redemption
Human effort alone secures salvation without God’s involvement
God’s sovereignty excludes any human participation
Salvation is purely accidental without purpose
questions.correctAnswer: Human obedience works in harmony with God’s sovereign plan to accomplish redemption
questions.explanation: Ruth’s actions following Naomi’s advice (Ruth 3:5-6) demonstrate human obedience cooperating with God’s sovereign plan (Philippians 2:12-13, Romans 8:28), revealing salvation history as a divine-human partnership rather than unilateral action.
